title: Mary Bernard Aguirre
text:
Mary Bernard Aguirre (June 23, 1844 – May 24, 1906) was a public <a href="schoolteacher">schoolteacher</a> and instructor at the <a href="University%20of%20Arizona">University of Arizona</a>. 
Early life.
Bernard Aguirre was born in <a href="St.%20Louis%2C%20Missouri">St. Louis, Missouri</a>. She was the daughter of a wealthy merchant, Joab Bernard (1800–1879) and 
Arabella Mather Bier Bernard (1816–1899). For the first twelve years of her life the family resided in <a href="Baltimore">Baltimore, Maryland</a>, the birthplace of Mary's mother. In 1856 the Bernard family moved to <a href="Westport%2C%20Missouri">Westport, Missouri</a>, where Mary's father owned a large store.
Bernard Aguirre went to college at the age of seventeen; this would prove to be a critical period of her life, as she lived through many moments that eventually changed her views towards people of other races. She heard the <a href="rifle">rifle</a> shot that killed <a href="Abolitionism%20in%20the%20United%20States">abolitionist</a> <a href="John%20Brown%20%28abolitionist%29">John Brown</a> in <a href="Harpers%20Ferry%2C%20West%20Virginia">Harpers Ferry, West Virginia</a>.
When Mary Bernard returned home from <a href="Baltimore%2C%20Maryland">Baltimore, Maryland</a> later that same year, the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a> broke out, and she became a supporter of the Southern cause.
Personal life.
Mary Bernard married a <a href="Mexico">Mexican</a> <a href="Freight%20transport">freighting</a> contractor, <a href="Epifanio%20Aguirre">Epifanio Aguirre</a>, on August 21, 1862 in <a href="Westport%2C%20Kansas%20City%2C%20Missouri">Westport</a>. The Aguirres had three sons: Pedro, (born 1863), Epifanio Jr. (born 1865) and Stephen (born 1867).
Bernard Aguirre's family moved to the Southwest in 1863. They traveled from Missouri to <a href="Las%20Cruces%2C%20New%20Mexico">Las Cruces, New Mexico</a>, with a stop in <a href="Santa%20Fe%2C%20New%20Mexico">Santa Fe</a>. Mary kept a journal of her family's travels across the <a href="Great%20Plains">Great Plains</a>.
In August 1869, the Aguirres set foot in <a href="Tucson%2C%20Arizona">Tucson</a>. In January 1870, Epifanio Sr. was killed during an <a href="Apache">Apache</a> raid of a <a href="stagecoach">stagecoach</a> near <a href="Sasabe%2C%20Arizona">Sasabe, Arizona</a>. In economic straits, Bernard Aguirre saw herself forced to return home to Missouri and live with her parents.
Career.
In 1874, Mary Bernard Aguirre returned to Tucson, having accepted a job as a teacher in <a href="Tres%20Alamos%2C%20Arizona">Tres Alamos</a>. She taught in <a href="Tucson%2C%20Arizona">Tucson</a>-area public schools, including the <a href="Tucson%20Public%20School%20for%20Girls">Tucson Public School for Girls</a>, for four years. During this time, Bernard Aguirre advocated for public education against the prevailing inclination among <a href="Catholicism">Catholics</a> towards homeschooling.
In 1878, she became the first teacher in <a href="Arivaca%2C%20Arizona">Arivaca</a>, sixty miles south of Tucson; during her tenure she was recruited to teach at the fledgling <a href="University%20of%20Arizona">University of Arizona</a>.
She became chair of the <a href="Spanish%20language">Spanish language</a> and <a href="English%20history">English history</a> departments at the <a href="University%20of%20Arizona">University of Arizona</a> in 1885. She was the university's first female professor, and resigned from the post in 1901.
In 1906, Mary Bernard Aguirre was injured in a <a href="sleeping%20car">Pullman</a> <a href="train">train</a> crash in <a href="California">California</a>. On May 24, 1906, two weeks after the accident, she died of internal injuries.
